section.title: Annuity Valuations at Other Points in Time
section.p: In the last activity we met deferred annuities. This was an example of valuing an annuity (or perpetuity) at various points on the timeline. In general, we push our present/future values forward or pull them backward along the timeline to the point where we want to value.

assemblage.title: 🧮 Calculator Tip
assemblage.p: As with deferred annuities, you can use the financial calculators to value an annuity at any point in time. As needed, calculate the future or present value, then hit either the PV or FV button (depending on if you are pulling back or pushing forward), make PMT 0, and change the value for N. If needed, you may also have to change I/Y if the rate changes (although we will deal more with that in ).

introduction.p: Payments of 100 per quarter are made from June 7, Z (Z is the year) through December 7, Z+11, inclusive. If the nominal rate of interest convertible quarterly is 6%:

task.p: Find the present value on September 7, Z-1.
Find the current value on March 7, Z+8.
Find the accumulated value on June 7, Z+ 12.

statement.p: Logan Roy has gifted an annuity to his grandnephew Greg Hirsch. The annuity pays 3 million per year for 10 years, starting at the end of this year. Greg deposits each payment into an account earning an effective annual interest rate of \iota = 3\%. Sixteen years from today (six years after the last payment), Greg wants to purchase a small, progressive newspaper for 45 million. How much is in the account at this point? How much additional funding would he need to make the purchase?

Suppose Siobhan Roy purchases an annuity that pays 5 million per year for 15 years, but starting 5 years from the time of purchase. The annuity is valued at an effective annual interest rate of \iota = 5\%. If Siobhan purchased the annuity today, what did she pay for it?
Describe how we value annuities at different points in time. What do you think will be tricky?
